newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed down across the board on Tuesday on a powerful technical correction after sharp rises on Monday, traders said.
The annual rate for the most active seven-day contract plunged to 11.4 percent from 30 percent on Monday.
Total turnover of the six-contract market fell to 7.2 million lots from 13.1 million.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
"The correction has been expected after surges on Monday as the (domestic) A share bull run continues," a trader said.
"Despite today's fall, the performance of the A share markets will continue to be the biggest single market-moving factor for the repo contracts," said a second trader.
"Continued heavy issues of new A shares are expected to support the repo rates in the medium term," he added.

Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended up across the board due to a strong technical rebound supported by high yields of the existing countract after successive losses in the past few weeks, traders said.
The most active 10-year bond maturing in 2006 rose to 117.40 yuan from 116.29 yuan.
Combined volume of the seven-contract market more than doubled to 1.9 million lots. Spot prices had fallen in recent weeks with the active A share markets sucking money out of the spot market.
But the contracts now have an average yield of around 10 percent per year, much higher than the 7.47 percent rate for one-year bank deposits, supporting Tuesday's technical rebound, traders said.

"Market sentiment is good because of the high yields," said one trader. "But the rising A share markets have indicated even higher returns in the past few weeks. The perfomance of the A markets will continue to be a key factor in the near term."
